datasetContactAffiliation.value: University of California, Los Angeles. Social Science Data Archive.

dsDescriptionValue.value: This study focuses on current and retrospective information obtained from 4104 women age 15-45 in Nicaragua. There are four areas of concentration. 1) Economic activity of the respondent and other members of the household; 2) Fertility and contraceptive behavior; 3) Health and nutritional status of family members and use of medical facilities; 4) Other background variables, including marital and migratory status, education, attitudes and intensity of religious observance of the family, parents and spouse of the respondent.  Wave I has 700 variables; Wave II has 500, and there are 760 variables in Wave III.

value: Social Sciences

Subject: STANDARD DEPOSIT TERMS 1.0  Type: DATAPASS:TERMS:STANDARD:1.0  Notes: The UCLA Social Science Data Archive (“the Archive”) gives permission and any required licenses to Data-PASS to make the Content available for archiving, preservation and access (with permission of the Archive), within the Data Preservation Alliance for the Social Sciences ("Data-PASS") in accordance with the Data-PASS terms (the "Terms") of use (available from: http://www.icpsr.org/Data-PASS). Including permission to: (a) redisseminate copies of the Data Collection in a variety of distribution formats only according to the standard terms of use of the Archive; (b) promote and advertise the Data Collection in any publicity (in any form) for Data-PASS and the Archive; (c) describe, catalog, validate and document the Content; (d) store, translate, copy or re-format the Data Collection in any way to ensure its future preservation and accessibility, improve usability and/or protect respondent confidentiality; (e) incorporate metadata (cataloging information) or documentation regarding this study into public access catalogues. The Archive represents and warrants that the Content conforms to all Terms and that the Archive is lawfully entitled and has full authority to license Data-Pass to use the Materials in the ways described in the Terms.;

value: Survey

Socioeconomic Characteristics of women in a Developing Country and the Degree of Urbanization by Jere R. Behrman, et al. Institute for Research on Poverty Discussion Paper 655-81. Madison, WI: University of Wisconsin, Institute for Research on Poverty, 1980
Behrman, Jere R. and Barbara L. Wolfe.  "How Does Mother's Schooling Affect Family Health, Nutrition, Medical Care Usage, and Household Sanitation?"  Journal of Econometrics, vol. 36 (1987): 185-204.

Behrman, Jere R. and Barbara L. Wolfe.  "Investments in Schooling in Two Generations in Pre-Revolutionary Nicaragua: The Roles of Family Background and School Supply."  Journal of Development Economics, vol. 27 (1987): 395-419.

Behrman, Jere R. and Barbara L. Wolfe.  "Labor Force Participation and Earnings Determinants for Women in the Special Conditions of Developing Countries."   Journal of Development Economics, vol. 15 (1984): 259-288.

Behrman, Jere R. and Barbara L. Wolfe.  "Micro Determinants of Female Migration in a Developing Country: Labor Market, Demographic Marriage Market and Economic Marriage Market Incentives."  Research in Population Economics, vol. 5 (1984): 137-166.
Behrman, Jere R. and Barbara L. Wolfe.  "More Evidence on Nutrition Demand: Income Seems Overrated and Women's Schooling Underemphasized."  Journal of Development Economics, vol. 14 (1984): 105-128.
Behrman, Jere R. and Barbara L. Wolfe.  "The Socioeconomic Impact of Schooling in a Developing Country."  The Review of Economics Statistics, vol. LXVI, no. 2 (May 1984): 296-303.

Behrman, Jere R., Barbara L. Wolfe and David M. Blau.  "Human Capital and Earnings Distribution in a Developing Country: The Case of Prerevolutionary Nicaragua."  Economic Development and Cultural Change, vol. 34 (1985): 1-29.

Blau, David M., Jere R. Behrman and Barbara L. Wolfe.  "Schooling and Earnings Distributions with Endogenous Labour Force Participation, Martial Status and Family Size."  Economica, vol. 55 (1988): 297-316.
Wolfe, Barbara L. and Jere R. Behrman.  "Determinants of Child Mortality, Health, and Nutrition in a Developing Country."  Journal of Development Economics, vol. 11 (1982): 163-193.

Wolfe, Barbara L. and Jere R. Behrman.  "Determinants of Women's Health Status and Health-Care Utilization in a Developing Country: A Latent Variable Approach."  The Review of Economics and Statistics, vol. LXVI
, no. 4 (November 1984): 696-703.
Wolfe, Barbara L. and Jere R. Behrman.  "Is Income Overrated in Determining Adequate Nutrition?"  Economic Development and Cultural Change, vol. 31 (1983): 525-549.

Wolfe, Barbara L. and Jere R. Behrman.  "Is Schooling Productivity in Developing Countries Often Misunderstood?"  In Anita A. Summers, (ed.), New Directions for Testing and Measurement: Productivity Assessment in Education, San Francisco: Jossey-Bass Publishing Co., (September 1982): 61-77.

Wolfe, Barbara L. and Jere R. Behrman.  "The Synthesis Economic Fertility Model: A Latent Variable Investigation of Some Critical Attributes."  Journal of Population Economics, vol. 5, no. 1 (1992): 1-16.

Wolfe, Barbara L. and Jere R. Behrman.  "Who is Schooled in Developing Countries?  The Role of Income, Parental Schooling, Sex, Residence and Family Size."  Economics of Education Review, vol. 3, no. 3 (1984): 231-245.

Wolfe, Barbara L. and Jere R. Behrman.  "Women's Schooling and Children's Health: Are the Effects Robust with Adult Sibling Control for the Women's Childhood Background?"  Journal of Health Economics, vol. 6 (1987): 239-254.
Wolfe, Barbara L., Jere R. Behrman and David M. Blau.  "The Impact of Demographic Changes on Income Distribution in a Developing Country."  Journal of Development Economics, vol. 11 (1982): 355-377.

Wolfe, Barbara L., Jere R. Behrman, Humberto Belli, Kathleen Cairns, and Nancy Williamson. "Socioeconomic Characteristics of Women in a Developing Country and the Degree of Urbanization." (PDF, 2.21 Mb) Institute for Research on Poverty Discussion Paper. Madison, Wisconsin, 1980.

fields.value: The study used a stratified random sampling technique to collect 3409 interviews; the other 695 interviews with sisters of the original respondents.
